content.body: AryehGregor: I think that a lot of them are disabled or work closely with the disabled.

pong
anyone know what the mimetype for truetype fonts is?
My /etc/mime.types says application/x-font-ttf
there's no officially defined ones, IIRC
though I've seen people pushing font/ttf, font/otf, font/eot, and font/woff lately
Hixie: could i have your opinion about @autocomplete related bugs ?
just to know if i should go on the direction of bug 9637 or you have a big reason to refuse
given how much people push mime you'd think they would maintain the registry so that this kind of thing was easy to answer
it's not like fonts are rare or something
volkmar: which bug system? mozilla, webkit, w3c...?
Hixie: w3c
volkmar: i expect we can't change the autocomplete stuff, it's been implemented for more than a decade now
Hixie: i thought autocomplete IDL attribute has been introduced with html5
volkmar: IE6 didn't distinguish between IDL and content attributes
Hixie: hmmm, is that really a blocker ?
i dunno
if we want to change it though we have to prove it's not a problem to change it, because with something that old, the safest guess is that it's impossible to change
the only real difference that would happen between @autocomplete and .autocomplete is when @autocomplete is not set or set to an invalid value
i doesn't sound really critic, does it ?
points to the /topic
Hixie: ok
the web is a weird palce
place
people do all kinds of things we don't expect
seriously though, unless there's a really important reason to worry about it, i would recommend not touching it
Hixie: btw, who/what should use autocomplete except UAs ?
how do you mean?
it's most commonly used by banks
google.com uses it too
Hixie: sorry, i wasn't clear
i mean, websites _sets_ autocomplete, the value is for the UA, right ?
yes
then the web shouldn't care about what .autocomplete returns
... or that's still too much thinking about the wild web
who knows
people do crazy things
often without good reason

Of course, you've got to restart whatever programs were updated.

hsivonen: I enjoyed your http://hsivonen.iki.fi/-webkit-html5/ article. another problem is it’s hard for authors to know what vendor prefixes to add. is there a resource listing what CSS things have vendor prefixes? if not can we set a wiki up somewhere?

hsivonen: also you might want to mention in the conclusion that for bits of the spec that are implemented the same way using vendor prefixes by more than one browser it’s good to add the non-prefixed version too, for future support.
bbl
boblet: adding the non-prefixed version (which I do on my site) defeats the point of prefixes, too
boblet: since it creates a body of legacy content that assumes that standardized syntax works the same as the initial prefixed syntax

boblet: as I see it, the only real solution is to speed up the process from having two implementations to the point where the prefix is removed and the CSS WG agrees not to bikeshed the feature anymore
boblet: and to make that happen, vendors should be required to contribute sufficient editor time to the CSS WG when they come up with a CSS extension
boblet: but there's no way to enforce such a person-time contribution rule

TabAtkins_: The a11y people seem to have rather different ideas about what constitues ideal alt text. For example they seem to assume that the user should be informed that there is an image, and get a description of the image. Having the page work as if there were no images in the first place doesn't seem to be a goal
It would be interesting to test what is most helpful to actual users
jgraham: the "a11y people" aren't a unified "they" on this point
hsivonen: Fiar enough
*Fair
hsivonen: I seem to be running into a problem with the v.nu servlet output... Is there some character limit on the length of error messages it will emit?
MikeSmith: of an individual error message? I can't recall.
MikeSmith: is this in Jetty or in Jigsaw?
Jetty
running locally from my workspace
MikeSmith: how does the problem manifest itself?
hsivonen: If I validate a certain file directly from the command-line with Jing, I get the following error message:
http://paste.plurk.com/show/267869/
TabAtkins_: I'm not sure I agree it's easy either. For example I don't see the value of Hixie's alt text for the Blammo Corp example
but if I try it with my local v.nu install, I get "error: " but with no message text
but I do get the line number info and markup fragment
MikeSmith: and does the rest of the result page show up?
ok
hsivonen: yeah
jgraham: it's not clear to me that there's much value in making that kind of image accessible either
I'm suspecting a bug in the code that formats the message
TabAtkins_: Whatever the photograph is trying to communicate, it is not "Our CEO is tall and has brown hair and a moustache"
jgraham: my argument was not that my suggestion made it useful, but that it made it accessible
hsivonen: OK, I can play around it some more and see if I can figure anything out on my own
jgraham: is that an actual alt text?
hsivonen: No, it is a hypothetical one
hsivonen: fwiw, I get no indication of a problem on the console log from v.nu
Hixie: I think that is too reductionist a viewpoint
I don't think you can say "is this image accessible"
Only "is this content accessible"
where content === whole page, typically
jgraham: well that's as may be, but bruce was applying it to the figure, which is what i applied it to
jgraham: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/html-wg/20070927#l-332
Hixie: I think my point is that the thread is trying to look at <figure>s in isolation, which is a silly thing to do
jgraham: personally i'd be fine with not making the photograph accessible, since it's almost certainly purely decorative in context, but we shouldn't pretend that that means it's accessible
jgraham: couldn't agree more
hsivonen: Indeed
(i'd omit the alt attribute in the case)

Semantic question: what sets a heading apart from a dt? The dt is defined as a term part of a term-description group. But isn't also a heading in a way a term, describing the content that follows it?
Andros: you wouldn't put the terms of a term-description group into a book's table of contents
Andros: and you wouldn't put the headings of a book into its index
Andros: the expectation is that headings appear in an outline but dts don't
Hixie: still drinking coffee so am apparently a little slow on the Google, but I’m now reading CSS3 Lists which you edited :)
boblet: :-)
hsivonen & hixie: I think I see what you're meaning.

i haven't been paying close attention...
gsnedders: you'd need negative mass to get faster than light
is around a month behind on email

Hixie: Ah, true. Duh.
hopes he's remembering his relativity maths well enough
You are.
(I think. jgraham will now say we're both wrong.)
No, once you get down to zero mass things get "interesting" but you can't travel faster than light
(light itself has zero rest mass for example)
Surely it therefore also has zero relativisty mass for all values of v?
and antimatter has still positive mass?
Yes
should point out the implied "in a vacuum")
(since you can travel faster than light in a non-vacuum)
negative mass is basically a meaningless concept like time before the big bang, if i'm not mistaken
doesn't care about places apart from in a vacnuum on a frictionless bench
is reminded of xkdc with physicists in a frictionless vacuum
that xkcd is such a lie
the professor and the laptop would both more or less disintegrate if friction was zero

a way that doesn't involve changing the laws of biology and engineering? :-)

notes that the whole everything-is-HTML5 thing is the unexpectedly sour taste of victory (to quote Green Wing), so it's probably not worth getting to upset about

haha
hmm. They also claim to support article, section, etc. But they don't support the proper heading level algorithm, so that's really only a half truth.

Lachy: That's not really true. We have the two biggest tech brands on the planet fighting to leverage the mindshare that HTML5 has. Compare to http://www.456bereastreet.com/archive/200705/help_keep_accessibility_and_semantics_in_html/

If going from "you might be better off not using HTML5" to Apple trying to make anything and everything "HTML5" because it has such positive assosiations isn't victory I don't know what you were expecting

Sure, it's great that they're promoting HTML5, but it would be better if they would use the proper terminology for things that aren't in HTML5 instead of lumping it all together

I guess victory is having good technology and having lots of people use it (and marketing just helps with the latter)

hey all, re: <dl> I’ve had two ppl say today that dt/dd associations need an explicit wrapping element. one said it’s annoying to style and another said it’s hard to manipulate in Javascript. would the solution just to be make each name-value association an individual <dl>? so a description list becomes a list of multiple <dl> elements, each wrapping one name-value association
boblet: in theory that breaks semantics
boblet: Not sure whether it's a Real Problem, though.
hsivonen: in the styling case you’d need to apply classes to both dt and dd to style a name-value association

I’m guessing that we’re not able to put in eg a wrapping div to style a name-vale association (I think that’s what this means: “If a dl element contains non-whitespace text nodes, or elements other than dt and dd, then those elements or text nodes do not form part of any groups in that dl.”)

jgraham: The purpose of the photograph is to provide a physical depiction of the CEO. Thus in this case a description is appropriate, as you need the caption to be referring to something (in most other cases it is purely decorative and so should receive the empty string).

it is very unlikely to be "to help the users identify the CEO in an identity parade"

is there a reason why valueAsNumber is a double instead of a float ?
volkmar: I'd assume it's because javascript numbers are doubles
Dashiva: why not but then there is a lake of consistency as progress element has only float attributes
and the specs say we should apply "the rules for parsing floating point number values"
Hmm, so valueAsNumber is the only use of double?
afaict
Dashiva: even if it could be great to have double for progress.position
It seems valueAsNumber is used for date-based inputs, using float there wouldn't be future-proof I guess?
It used to be float, but was increased to double on request
Dashiva: then, it explains why the spec say we should parse it with the float rule
i suppose it should be changed if we keep float
s/we keep float/you keep double/

OK, I switched over to Chrome 6.0.422.0 dev (Linux) to work out the new WebSocket handshake.  By using injected inputs of both the link Hixie gave me http://junkyard.damowmow.com/433 and the examples in the spec , I get the expected results , but when I use the request from Chrome , Key 3 looks odd as does the result and of course it does not work.     I've posted examples of the input and resulting output for all three cases at h
drclue, cut off after "all three cases at".
http://hg.diveintohtml5.org/hgweb.cgi/rev/31e07449843a7982c119bc7fe2c69b595a7e46f5 -- did someone tell hsivonen? :)

...all three cases at http://www.drclue.net/ws.html     The only thing I'm modifying in my code is the handshake , and the code did work before, and does work with the example requests, just not in Chrome.   The only thing that strikes me as odd are the values for the fields "host" and "origin" , which sorta seem transposed in the request as relates to what I think I'm reading in the spec

In the spec it says that the "origin" request field should contain the scheme, hostname, and port  , but the chrome request only has the scheme and hostname , and not the port.  The "host" request field has the port tacked on the end though, and I'm not even sure that should be there
The only time the "origin" request field is supposed to exclude the port reference is if it is the default port, but I'm using port 10812
So am I just missing something obvious , or is something besides me broken here?
drclue: afaict both host and origin should include non-defaul ports

Hey I am new to JS and I just wrote a small blog on Webstorage and HTML5 that I had studied in the past few days... Now I wanted to know some good place where I can post it so I could have some discussion and FB....
The random bytes from Chrome, as written on your website look screwy
kpx: I don't really understand the question
@jgraham  I most certainly agree they look way wrong.   Check out the "host" and "origin" fields in the request. Do those jive with your understanding of the spec?
drclue: origin should have a port, at least
drclue: Origin is the origin of the page which runs the script that opens the websocket
As in I used to submit blog entries to hacker news and all... Is there some place like taht for HTML5 and all?
Ah, that's a good point
If you are running the page on port 80 it shoudln't
@jgraham so what ya figure gives with the odd looking key 3?
kpx: Not really.
drclue, if it's the default port of the scheme the origin production will not include the port
so http,80 -> no port; https,443 -> no port; http,81 -> port; etc.
OK, , I'm with ya on the origin
I still don't get this thing with the odd looking key 3.
drclue: looks like you're converting key3 to characters
drclue: key3 is random bytes
drclue: don't decode them to a string

volkmar: I checked the discussion from when it was changed, and it turns out float won't work at all since the timestamp is milliseconds and not seconds
Dashiva: Why does the scale matter? Doesn't that just mean the maximum is 10^34 seconds, not 10^37 seconds?
(so it's still plenty of ages of the universe)
Philip`: Timestamps need to be precise, so a float is pretty much a 24-bit integer in this regard
But I suppose you're right, and float would be too small even for seconds
Oh, so the issue is that it has a precision of milliseconds and a range of >2^24 larger than that, rather than the issue being that it's scaled to milliseconds
Things would be much easier if time didn't change so frequently
Sounds like you're onto something
24fps is enough for visually smooth animation in films, so we could just quantise the universe to ~100Hz and nobody would notice
I'm pretty sure we'd notice when chemistry stopped working.  Well, actually, we wouldn't, but for entirely the wrong reason.
It seems today's date requires 31 bits for second precision, 41 for millisecond precision
It requires 0 seconds for arbitrary precision, if you pick the start date correctly.
It requires 0 bits for arbitrary precision, if you pick the start date correctly.
Sadly, we have a bit of a legacy environment to consider
